parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The post does not contain a CMF number. While the absence of a CMF number is not automatically disqualifying, it suggests the post might not be directly from a registered candidate or party.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post explicitly mentions Emanuel Cioaca, a candidate for the Senate, and the ADN party.  It clearly identifies a specific candidate and party participating in the parliamentary elections. This fulfills "Article 36 (7) - a".</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The use of hashtags further amplifies its potential reach, indicating an intention to address the public at large. This satisfies "Article 36 (7) - c".</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The primary objective of the post is to encourage voters to support Emanuel Cioaca and the ADN party in the upcoming parliamentary elections.  Phrases like "Votam masiv" (Vote massively) and "Votam Alternativa pentru Demnitatea Națională - ADN!" (Vote for the Alternative for National Dignity - ADN!) directly aim to influence voting behavior. This clearly fulfills "Article 36 (7) - c".</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post does not present itself as journalistic content. It lacks objective reporting, analysis, or diverse perspectives. Instead, it promotes a specific candidate and party, lacking the neutrality expected of journalistic work.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The content is not a personal opinion; it's a clear call to action promoting a specific candidate and party in the election.  The statement is not an expression of personal belief but a direct appeal for votes.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>531685073178199</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, paid for by Federatia Romanilor de Pretutindeni, promotes Emanuel Cioaca (ADN) for the Senate elections.  The post's language ("Votam masiv," "Votam ADN!") directly encourages voters to support a specific candidate and party.  The targeting of the ad (Cluj County, Romania) and the use of hashtags further indicate an attempt to influence voters.  While the post doesn't explicitly violate Article 36 (7) by mentioning the candidate's name and party, the clear intention to influence the vote during the election period makes it electoral propaganda.  The post's content and context strongly suggest it aims to sway public opinion in favor of a specific candidate, fulfilling all criteria of Article 36 (7).
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>Emanuel Cioaca</name><impact>POSITIVE</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>FRP</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
Federatia Romanilor de Pretutindeni, pentru incalcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei reclame pe Facebook dupa ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, cu ID-ul 531685073178199, care promoveaza in mod explicit candidatul Emanuel Cioaca pentru Senat din partea ADN, folosind fraze precum "Votam masiv" si "Votam ADN!", avand ca efect electoral influentarea votului in favoarea candidatului mentionat.  Reclama, platita de FRP, indeplineste toate criteriile materialului de propaganda electorala conform articolului 36 (7) din LEGEA nr. 334 din 17 iulie 2006, fiind adresata publicului larg si avand ca obiectiv clar influentarea votului.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
